questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with oliguria, haematuria, and pedal edema over the past 3 days. He complains that his symptoms worsened rapidly. On examination, he has a BP of 190/140 mmHg. Blood workup shows elevated serum creatinine and blood urea. Histological studies show crescents in the glomeruli as seen in the image below. Which of the following type of nephritis does the clinical scenario suggest?
questions.solution:
The rapidly worsening symptoms and the histologic picture are suggestive of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) also known as crescentic glomerulonephritis. 

It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents. The disease progresses rapidly and leads to renal failure in weeks to months when not treated. In the majority of the cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. In pauci-immune type of RPGN, circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in most cases. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes.

Other options:

Option B: Minimal change disease - presence of difuse effacement of podocytes (epithelial cell foot process) which is characteristic. It is one of the common causes of nephrotic syndrome. However, this glomerular abnormality can only be detected using electron microscopy and appear normal by light microscopy. 

Option C: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis - presence of focal and segmental scarring of the glomeruli most prominently seen at the corticomedullary junction.

Option D: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis - presence of thickenend glomerular basement membrane with mesangioproliferation and are of three types where type 1 is associated with hepatitis C infection while type 2 and 3 are idiopathic or complement mediated.

Related Pearl: Types of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

Immunofluorescence:

questions.text: A 19-year-old female patient comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness, amenorrhea, and fatigue.  Upon eliciting a history, she reveals that she is always worried about gaining weight. Her mother complains that she does not eat well. Her BMI is 15.8 kg/m². Laboratory findings in this patient will show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of anorexia nervosa. Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone is seen in a patient with anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder in which the patient has intense fear of becoming fat. This fear leads to restriction of calorie intake resulting in significantly reduced body weight. The patient does not understand the seriousness of the reduced body weight and continues to restrict food intake. Some patients might also have history of self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas. Laboratory investigations of these patients might show leukopenia with relative lymphocytosis, hypokalemic alkalosis, hypoglycemia, elevated serum salivary amylase levels, hypercholesterolemia, amenorrhea, mild hypothyroidism, and hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder that is characterized by self-induced starvation to a significant degree, drive for thinness or a morbid fear of fatness, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms resulting from starvation.

Investigations in anorexia nervosa:

  • Complete blood count: Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis
  • Serum electrolyte: Hypokalemic alkalosis (Purging)
  • Fasting serum glucose: Often low (emaciated phase) (Option D)
  • Serum salivary amylase: Often elevated (if the patient is vomiting)
  • ECG: ST segment and T-wave changes (secondary to electrolyte disturbances)
  • Hypotension and bradycardia
  • High serum cholesterol level (Option A)
  • Endocrine changes (caused by the underweight):
    • Amenorrhea
    • Hypothyroidism (Option B)
    • Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, low-grade fever, and chronic cough. On examination, the skin over the right shin has red nodules. An X-ray of the chest shows the following. The sputum sample sent for AFB testing comes back negative. What is the stage of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing weight loss, lowgrade fever, chronic cough, erythema nodosum, and a chest radiograph showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates is suggestive of Stage II Pulmonary Sarcoidosis.

Pulmonary sarcoidosis can be classified on a chest radiograph into 5 stages:

  • Stage 0: Normal chest radiograph.
  • Stage I: Hilar or mediastinal nodal enlargement only.
  • Stage II: Nodal enlargement and parenchymal disease
  • Stage III: Parenchymal disease only
  • Stage IV: End-stage lung (pulmonary fibrosis)

Radiographic features are variable depending on the stage of the disease.

Stage 0: Normal chest radiograph.
Stage I: Hilar or mediastinal nodal enlargement only.

Stage II: Nodal enlargement and parenchymal disease.

Stage III: Parenchymal disease only.

Stage IV: End-stage lung (pulmonary fibrosis)

Above image depicts signs and symptoms of sarcoidosis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He presented with pallor, cold sweats, weakness, lightheadedness, thirst, and rapid breathing. On examination he was found to be mildly anxious and confused, and several bruises and lacerations in his limbs with vitals as follows :
Heart rate - 132 bpm
Blood Pressure - 90/60 mmHg.
Based on the clinical signs, what is the estimated percentage of blood loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features showing mild tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotensive with anxiety and confusion is suggestive of Class III of hypovolemic (hemorrhagic) shock where the percentage of blood loss is estimated to be 30 - 40 % ( ~ 1.5L).

A detailed classification of hemorrhagic shock along with various clinical signs is as given below.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The image portrayed above shows the Dugas' test which is used in the diagnosis of anterior dislocation of the shoulder. 

The patient is seated and places the hand of the affected shoulder on the opposite shoulder. The patient is instructed to touch the chest with the elbow. Inability to do so indicates shoulder subluxation or dislocation.

Four tests are used to diagnose anterior dislocation of the shoulder. These include Bryant's test, Dugas test, Hamilton ruler test, and Callaway test.  

 

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

questions.text:
A young man visits the fever clinic with a history of high-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite for the past 5 days. RT-PCR is done and he has been diagnosed with moderate COVID-19 disease. Awake proning has been advised. What is the sequence to be followed?
  1. Left lateral decubitus
  2. Prone position
  3. Upright position
  4. Right lateral decubitus
questions.solution:
The patient has moderate COVID-19 disease and awake proning is recommended in such patients. Typical protocol includes:

  • 30–120 minutes in the prone position, followed by 
  • 30–120 minutes in the left lateral decubitus
  • 30–120 minutes in right lateral decubitus
  • 30–120 minutes in upright sitting position

Awake proning should be encouraged in all patients who require supplemental oxygen therapy. 

Criteria to be fulfilled :

  • Normal mental status
  • Able to self-prone or change position with minimal assistance

Avoid proning in :

  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Close monitoring is not possible

Important considerations while proning:

  • Early self-proning in awake, non-intubated patients
  • Any COVID-19 patient with respiratory embarrassment severe enough to be admitted to the hospital may be considered for rotation and early self-proning
  • Care must be taken to not disrupt the flow of oxygen during patient rotation

Management of Moderate cases of COVID-19 :

  • Symptomatic treatment such as antipyretic (paracetamol) for fever and pain, and anti-tussive for cough. Continue medications for co-morbid conditions.
  • Adequate hydration to be ensured
  • Oxygen Support: Target SpO2: 92-96% (88-92% in patients with COPD).
  • Anticoagulation-prophylactic dose of un-fractionated heparin (UFH) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) (e.g enoxaparin 0.5 mg /Kg body wt per day SC)
  • Anti-inflammatory or immunomodulatory therapy- IV methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1 mg/kg or IV dexamethasone 0.1 to 0.2 mg/kg usually for a duration of 5 to 10 days.
  • Antibiotics should not be prescribed routinely unless there is clinical suspicion of a bacterial infection.
  • Awake proning: should be encouraged in all patients who require supplemental oxygen therapy. 
  • Monitoring for hemodynamic instability, and change in oxygen requirement. HRCT chest is to be done only if there is a worsening.
  • Lab monitoring: Monitor CRP and D-dimer 48 to 72 hourly, and complete blood count, and renal and liver function tests 24 to 48 hourly. IL-6 levels should be done if the patient is deteriorating.
  • Remdesivir may be considered in patients who have
    • symptoms for less than 10 days
    • moderate to a severe disease requiring supplemental oxygen
    • Not pregnant and not lactating
    • No renal or hepatic impairment (eGFR <30 ml/min/m2; AST/ALT >5 times upper limit of normal
    • Dose: 200 mg IV on day 1 followed by 100 mg IV daily for 4 days (total 5 days)

questions.text: Which of the following muscles has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibres so that there is prolonged muscle activity in lower leg?
questions.solution:
Soleus muscle has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibers and therefore is used to a greater extent for prolonged lower leg muscle activity.

Fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers -

  • Fast-twitch fibers can deliver extreme amounts of power from a few seconds to a minute.
    • The enzymes that promote rapid release of energy from the phosphagen and glycogen–lactic acid energy systems are more active in fast-twitch fibers.
    • They are about twice as large in diameter compared with slow-twitch fibers.
    • Gastrocnemius muscle has a higher bulk of fast-twitch fibers, which gives it the capability of forceful and rapid contraction, commonly used in jumping.
  • Slow-twitch fibers are mainly organized for endurance, especially for the generation of aerobic energy.
    • They have more mitochondria than the fast-twitch fibers.
    • They also contain considerably more myoglobin. The extra myoglobin increases the rate of diffusion of oxygen throughout the fiber.
    • The enzymes of the aerobic metabolic system are considerably more active in slow-twitch fibers.
    • The number of capillaries is greater around the slow-twitch fibers.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with polymorphous, erythematous patches with itching over his lower limbs, buttocks, and chest for the past 3 years. He has cervical lymphadenopathy. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytes with a cerebriform appearance. What will be the histopathological examination findings in this case?

choices.text: Band like Lymphocytic infiltrate in dermo epidermal junction

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male with polymorphous, erythematous patches with pruritus and peripheral smear of lymphocytes with cerebriform appearance is suggestive of Mycosis fungoides. Lymphocyte-predominant micro abscesses known as Pautriers’s microabscesses are seen in this condition.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ Helper T cells) which usually stays confined to the skin. It usually involves limb/ girdle, breast, and especially the buttock area. It can disseminate into the blood which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Mycoses fungoides passes through 3 phases:

  • Inflammatory pre-mycotic phase- eczema-like lesions
  • Plaque phase- raised plaques are seen
  • Tumor phase- multiple tumor nodules indicating systemic spread

The image given below shows phases seen in mycosis fungoides.

Histological hallmark includes:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/ hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism - the invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.

The image given below shows histological markers seen in mycosis fungoides.

Other options

Option A: Neutrophil predominant micro abscess (Munro microabscess) is seen in Psoriasis.

Histopathological Features of Psoriasis

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (Acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and Parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in Malpighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in Stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in Dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

Remember:  M (munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis) and P (pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides).

Option C: Band like Lymphocytic infiltrate in dermo epidermal junction is seen in Lichen planus.

Histopathological features of Lichen planus:

  • Increase in epidermal Langerhans cells associated with a superficial perivascular infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes, impinging on the dermal–epidermal junction (DEJ).
  • Hyperkeratosis and Hypergranulosis
  • Pigment incontinence: This occurs as the melanin gradually moves into the dermis as a result of degeneration of keratinocytes.
  • The melanin in the dermis is then engulfed by the macrophages forming melanophages (Melanin-containing macrophages).
  • The degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max-Joseph Spaces.
  • The rete ridges are pointed at their lower end giving them Saw-toothed appearance.
  • Band like Lymphocytic infiltrate is present at the Dermoepidermal junction.
  • Degenerating/Apoptotic Basal epidermal cells are known as colloid bodies (also known as Cytoid bodies/Civatte bodies), which may appear singly or in clumps.

Image: Histopathology of Lichen Planus

Option D: Tubercles with peripheral lymphocytes is seen in Lupus vulgaris

Histology of Lupus vulgaris shows tubercles with scanty or absent central caseation, surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleate giant cells, are present in the superficial dermis. Peripheral lymphocytes are often prominent. Usually, tubercle bacilli are scanty or absent.

Section below shows epidermis with marked acanthosis and neutrophilic abcess mixed with debris in keratin layers. The papillary dermis shows epitheliod cell granuloma with multinucleated gaint cell. The granuloma are surrounded by plasma cells and lymphocytes. Few eosinophils are seen amidst chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate.

questions.text: In the gynaecology operation theater, preparation for a female sterilization procedure is being made. You notice the instrument in the image below placed on the table. Which procedure is going to be performed?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a falope ring applicator. It is used in laparoscopic tubal ligation. 

Falope ring sterilization is accomplished by applying elastic bands or a falope ring to the fallopian tubes.

The falope ring applicator’s tongs are opened and positioned around the tube approximately 3cm away from the cornu, where the silastic falope ring is applied. It draws up a portion of the tube and then pushes the ring onto the loop of the fallopian tube.

The major advantage is the elimination of thermocoagulation, as the Silastic ring controls most of the bleeding associated with the procedure. The occlusion is complete in a short segment and offers theoretical possibilities of tubal reconstruction. Other methods of laparoscopic tube sterilization include filshie clip sterilization and hulka clip sterilization.

Other options:

Option B: Madlener operation:  A loop of the tube is crushed and ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.

Option C: Uchida method: The serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, and then is excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

Option D: Pomeroy technique: It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation. The fallopian tube is identified, exposed through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop, tied at the base with catgut and excised. Failure of the procedure may later occur due to spontaneous canalization. The operation is simple, requires short hospitalization, and can be performed in a primary health center. It is surgically reversible.

questions.text: A patient presented with foreign body sensation, redness, and excessive watering from the right eye for 15 days after a twig brushed against his eye. On examination, an irregularly shaped ulcer with a whitish feathery appearance, and satellite lesions were seen in his right eye. Which among the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a fungal ulcer and the most appropriate treatment is amphotericin B drops.

Fungal or mycotic keratitis is commonly caused by Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida albicans. They are characteristically seen after injury with vegetative matter like thorns or wooden sticks.

Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but are usually milder in comparison to a bacterial ulcer. The clinical signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes
  • Dry slough with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs
    • Natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B drops are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium.
    • Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic antifungal agents such as oral ketoconazole or voriconazole are considered if the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated or in suspected endophthalmitis
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Removal of necrotic material by scraping with a spatula
    • Cauterization with pure carbolic acid or trichloracetic acid
    • Therapeutic keratoplasty 

The image below shows a fungal corneal ulcer with a hypopyon.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for a routine examination.  On examination, a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. Lungs are clear and the abdomen is soft and non-tender.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents typically with fixed wide split S2, a classic finding of atrial septal defect (ASD), a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease.

Atrial septal defects are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration. Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. 

A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard. Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum.

ASDs are classified according to location of the defect listed as follows:

  • Patent foramen ovale
  • Ostium secundum
  • Ostium primum
  • Sinus venosus
  • Coronary sinus

Murmurs are described based on intensity, frequency or pitch, quality, duration, configuration, primary location, and site of radiation. The intensity of a murmur is graded from 1-6 as follows: 

  • Grade 1 - Faint, can only be heard with special effort
  • Grade 2 - Faint but immediately audible
  • Grade 3 - Moderately loud
  • Grade 4 - Very loud
  • Grade 5 - Extremely loud and is audible with one edge of the stethoscope touching the chest wall
  • Grade 6 - Loud, audible with stethoscope removed from contact with the chest wall

Murmurs of intensity grade 4 and higher are generally accompanied by a thrill. 

Other options:

Option A: Eisenmeger syndrome occurs when an existing left to right shunt results in severe pulmonary hypertension and increased vascular resistance which reverses the shunt to form a right to left shunt. Patients with known congenital heart disease would present with worsening exertional dyspnea, swelling, volume retention, syncope, cyanosis, palpitations, or hemoptysis. 

Option B: In Ventricular septal defect are generally asymptomatic and have a loud, harsh, or blowing holosystolic murmur heard over the lower left sternal border. 

Option D: Pulmonary stenosis – It has a systolic ejection murmur best heard along the left upper sternal border minimally radiating to the lung fields. Other features seen in this condition include a sharp pulmonic ejection click after S1, heard during expiration, a split S2, elevated venous pressure, prominent a wave in jugulovenous pulse, right ventricular lift, and mild to moderate cyanosis.

questions.text: Which fibre is marked by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the internal capsule, which is a form of projection fiber.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of repeated sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this case?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of IgG2 results in recurrent sinopulmonary infections with encapsulated organisms.

IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and provides natural passive immunity to the newborn. IgG1 is the antibody maximally transported across the placenta, whereas IgG2 has the least transplacental movement. 

Deficiencies of other IgG: 

  • IgG1- bacterial infections (diphtheria, tetanus)(Option A)
  • IgG3- viral infections (Option C)
  • IgG4- parasitic infections (Option D)

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of having ingested one of the seeds shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: It acts by blocking the action of GABA in the spinal cord
Ingestion of one crushed seed causes fatality
Death is associated with postmortem caloricity

questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos-nux vomica which contains strychnine. It is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postsynaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature called postmortem caloricity. 

The toxin strychnine does not affect any receptors in the brain and the person remains conscious till death. Strychnine poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures. 

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine plant

Strychnine seeds

questions.text: The ECG of a patient undergoing treatment with a quinolone is given below and you notice that QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs has the highest risk of causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes QT interval prolongation (Normal QTc = 440 ms). Among the given options, moxifloxacin has the highest risk for causing this condition.

Gemifloxacin, ofloxacin, and ciprofloxacin have a relatively lower risk than moxifloxacin. Ciprofloxacin has the least risk for QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes. Sparfloxacin has the highest overall risk of QT prolongation and has been withdrawn from many countries due to its propensity to cause torsades de pointes or polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Trovafloxacin Hepatotoxicity

questions.text: An individual positive for HIV-1 infection was started on a combination ART regimen of tenofovir–emtricitabine–efavirenz. After 6 months, failure of treatment was established and attributed to efavirenz resistance. Which drug of the same class can be used instead?
questions.solution:
Etravirine can be used instead of efavirenz.

Etravirine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) currently approved for the treatment of HIV infection in combination with other agents in treatment-experienced patients.

Options A, B: Etravirine is active against strains of HIV that are resistant to other NNRTIs such as delavirdine, nevirapine, and efavirenz which all exhibit cross-resistance. Rilpivirine, an NNRTI, is also effective across a broad range of NNRTI-resistant viruses but shares cross-resistance with etravirine.

Option C: Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor and hence, does not belong to the same class.

questions.text: A patient with Wilm's tumor undergoes renal transplantation. He is currently on corticosteroid therapy to prevent organ rejection. All of the following vaccinations could be given to this patient except?
questions.solution:
Intra-nasal/ nasal spray influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient as he is immunosuppressed.

Live vaccines are prepared from live or wild attenuated organisms. They are repeatedly passed through tissue cultures or chick embryos in the laboratory. With this, they lose their ability to induce full-blown infection in an individual but retain their immunogenicity. It should not be administered to patients with immunodeficiency diseases, lymphoma, leukemia, or other malignancies. It is also not recommended in individuals on treatment with corticosteroids, antimetabolites, and alkylating agents. Unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm, it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine, which can be given in the immunocompromised.

Other options:

Option A: Diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) vaccine is a combination toxoid vaccine. The toxins produced by diphtheria and tetanus bacilli are detoxicated and used to prepare the vaccine. They are highly efficacious and safe. The killed whole organism is used for the pertussis component. 

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine. It is produced by inserting a viral gene segment into a yeast cell. It does not contain viral DNA and will not produce an infection.

Option D: Inactivated polio vaccine is a killed vaccine. As the organism cannot grow in a vaccinated individual, it can be given to an immunodeficient individual.

questions.text: The patient presents with pigmentation of the face as shown in the image below and gradually increasing backache and stiffness. The X-ray image of the spine is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical images show the accumulation of blackish discoloration on the face and the X-Ray shows calcification of the intervertebral discs. These findings are associated with alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is a condition caused due to the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. This results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

This condition is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Black ochronotic pigmentation (Alkapton bodies) of cartilage and collagenous tissue
  • Homogentisic aciduria (patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing)
  • Large joint arthritis
  • Calcification of intervertebral discs known as as ochronotic spondyloarthropathy

questions.text: Following is the otoscopic image of a surfer complaining of deafness. Pure tone audiometry is suggestive of conductive hearing loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic finding is suggestive of exostoses.

A surfer with a clinical diagnosis of a conductive type of hearing loss with the otoscopic image showing multiple, sessile bumpy swellings in the external auditory canal draws us to a diagnosis of exostoses.

Exostoses are bilateral multiple smooth sessile bony swellings in the deeper canal seen in surfers. It is also called as surfer’s ear. They can be removed with a high-speed drill to restore the normal external auditory canal.

The following CT image shows the difference between a normal ear canal and an ear canal with exostoses.

The following table differentiates osteoma and exostoses

Sessile, smooth

Ceruminoma: It is a tumour of modified sweat glands. It presents as a smooth, firm, skin-covered polypoid swelling in the outer part of the meatus. Wide surgical excision is done. 

Sebaceous adenoma: It arises from sebaceous glands of the meatus and presents as smooth, skin-covered swelling in the outer meatus. Treatment is surgical excision.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male comes to the emergency with a cardiac arrest and cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following capnographs would be obtained in this case?
questions.solution:
Image B represents the capnographic waveform seen while performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation. 

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. 

Uses of waveform capnography in CPR:

  • Evaluation of the effectiveness of chest compressions (<10 mmHg low EtCO2 suggests poor chest compressions)
  • Identification of return of spontaneous circulation (significant increase to 35–45 mmHg, due to drastic improvement of blood flow to the lungs)

It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism. It is now the desired investigation for assessing the effectiveness of chest compressions. 

Image A shows rebreathing of CO2, which may occur due to a faulty expiratory valve or an exhausted absorber system. 

Image C shows cardiac oscillations at the end of expiration as flow decreases and the beating heart causes emptying and filling of various parts of the lung with exhaled and fresh air. 

Image D shows malignant hyperthermia.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation
